description: {"blocks":[{"key":"85qj4","text":"This protocol details NEBNext® Immune Sequencing Kit (Human).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65cu6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gb2o","text":"https://www.neb.com/-/media/nebus/files/manuals/manuale6320.pdf?rev=1dca310ed12a4e89b322063d31db030d\u0026hash=D4D7E9FBED23CC7448447137DBFF8C0B","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":138}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"2EA30714726A11EC90210A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.neb.com/-/media/nebus/files/manuals/manuale6320.pdf?rev=1dca310ed12a4e89b322063d31db030d\u0026hash=D4D7E9FBED23CC7448447137DBFF8C0B"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"3cpjf","text":"Overview","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5cmjh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0odj","text":"Immune repertoire sequencing is a powerful tool that can be used to analyze the immune response to diseases and pathogens from current  and past exposures. Areas of particular interest include characterization of autoimmune diseases, oncology, discovery of neutralizing  antibodies against infectious disease, or use as a diagnostic tool for residual disease detection.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58vog","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8d2og","text":"In order to create the incredible genetic diversity required for antigen recognition by B and T Cells, lymphocytes construct unique antigen  receptors via a process known as V(D)J recombination. In this process, each cell selects a single V, D, and J gene segment through genetic  recombination, introducing additional non-germline-encoded nucleotides at the junctions. This process generates immune receptor  diversity, the majority of which is encoded in the heavy chain complementarity determining region 3 (CDR3) (Figure 1). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7a1rk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ljdd","text":"Recent improvements in the read length and throughput of next-generation sequencing (NGS) platforms have resulted in a rise in the  popularity of immune repertoire sequencing. The complex structure and sequence diversity of antibody-encoding genes have provided  significant challenges to the development of a simple and reliable method to sequence immune receptor sequences.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dmhfd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4uq2l","text":"The NEBNext Immune Sequencing Library Preparation Kit (Figure 2) provides all the components required for enrichment and sequencing of the B Cell Receptor (BCR) and T Cell Receptor (TCR) RNA transcripts present in a sample. NEBNext Immune Sequencing Kit has been developed and optimized to provide accurate sequencing of full-length immune transcript repertoires of B-cells and T-cells. This allows for exhaustive somatic mutation profiling across complete V, D and J segments, full isotype information analysis (IgM, IgD, IgG,  IgA and IgE), and also allows for synthesis and expression of complete antibody chains for downstream immunological assays. In addition,  this approach allows characterization of TRA and TRB chains. The method uses unique molecular identifier scheme specifically designed to barcode each mRNA molecule, allowing PCR copies derived from an individual mRNA to be collapsed into a single consensus sequence. This improves sequence accuracy by resolving PCR and sequencing errors. This also eliminates PCR bias, thus allowing for quantitative digital molecule counting.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4h7ti","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qh5v","text":"Defining features of the Immune Sequencing method include: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7006o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7m2ki","text":"a) Full-length variable sequences are generated (including isotype information), allowing downstream antibody synthesis and functional characterization not possible with approaches sequencing only the CDR3 region.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8b1u1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cae1d","text":"b) Variable region primers are not required, which reduces primer pool complexity and allows for the unbiased and simultaneous recovery of B Cell and T Cell receptor transcripts. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cjn0a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"23r1k","text":"c) Unique molecular barcoding approach minimizes PCR biases and improves sequencing accuracy by allowing a consensus to be generated from duplicate sequencing reads originating from the same transcript. Moreover, unique barcoding enables accurate quantitation of each clone present in the sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1kb9n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dalf2","text":"d) High target capture efficiency allows for immune repertoire sequencing and analysis from sub-microgram quantities of total RNA. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"149oe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bkprn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d56dp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c3jau","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"858rn","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b48or","text":"Step I-Prepare target RNA","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f74j3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5640j","text":"Immune Sequencing does not require mRNA isolation prior to library construction. Total RNA can be prepared from any sample or tissue  known to contain B Cells or T Cells, such as peripheral blood mononuclear cells, bone marrow, lymph nodes, or any other tissue in which  infiltrating lymphocytes are present. Cells or tissues can be frozen, but intact, high quality RNA is required for optimal performance. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ckdt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5hrei","text":"Step II-Perform molecular-tagging reverse transcription","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":55}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65us6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6kq51","text":"During this 50-minute reaction full-length mRNA is reverse transcribed and the 3´ end of each cDNA is tagged with a DNA adaptor  containing a unique molecular identifier (UMI) barcode.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3292r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8t6o2","text":"Step III-Purify with Streptavidin Magnetic Beads","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fquo3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"30nj7","text":"This 30-minute cleanup step removes all salts, reagents and unused cDNA adaptor oligonucleotides (TSO and RT Primers) allowing clean  downstream amplification steps. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nig9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"41g0","text":"Step IV-Primary amplification of target fragments","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":49}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fojbu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fkjq9","text":"This primary PCR step uses one primer which binds the universal cDNA adaptor and a primer mix targeting constant regions of the desired  immune receptors. Products are then purified with Sample Purification Beads. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lch0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6bpg","text":"Step V-Secondary PCR cycle optimization with real-time PCR","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":58}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ei14g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ajdtf","text":"This optional real-time PCR allows accurate assessment of target quantity leading to an optimized choice of PCR cycles for  the final library PCR.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"foqa8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ej3b","text":"Step VI-Secondary PCR including Illumina® adaptor addition","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":58}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2jlfi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6uk8","text":"This secondary PCR adds additional Illumina adaptor sequences to the target fragments (including Illumina multiplexing index  sequences if desired). After Sample Purification Bead cleanup the libraries are ready for Bioanalyzer or TapeStation analysis,  quantification and sequencing on the MiSeq platform. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fc4ca","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8m0pd","text":"Applications ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c3spq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6trbt","text":"The NEBNext Immune Sequencing Kit (Human) contains enzymes and buffers that are ideal to convert a small amount of human RNA  input into indexed libraries for next-generation sequencing on the Illumina® MiSeq platform (Illumina, Inc). The workflow of NEBNext  Immune Sequencing (Human) Kit is very user-friendly and fast with minimal hands-on time. Each of these components must pass rigorous  quality control standards and are lot controlled, both individually and as a set of reagents.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6a8r0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36e3c","text":" For larger volume requirements, customized and bulk packaging is available by purchasing through the OEM/Bulks department at NEB.  Please contact OEM@neb.com for further information.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"1ECC50A06EC211ECAF5E2B7ACD28FB86","height":231,"id":220689,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzsvbn3yf.jpg","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzstbn3yf.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzsubn3yf.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzssbn3yf.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"75E86CC06EC211ECAF5E2B7ACD28FB86","height":799,"id":220693,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzszbn3yf.jpg","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzsxbn3yf.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzsybn3yf.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gzswbn3yf.webp","width":550}}}}

One can achieve a similar result by manually taking an aliquot of the PCR reaction every 5 cycles and visualizing each aliquot on Bioanalyzer or TapeStation to identify the optimal cycling number that yields the highest product with the lowest background. The number of cycles should be high enough to provide sufficient library fragments for a successful sequencing run, but low enough to avoid PCR artifacts and over-cycling (high molecular weight fragments on Bioanalyzer).
